awd_titl_txt: Quantum Superpositions of Free Electron Orbital Angular Momentum
awd_abstract_narration:
Electrons are the tiniest particle of matter, the smallest spark of charge, and smallest bit of magnet. We power our cities with these small, charged, magnetic objects, and use them to store, process, and communicate information. It was recently discovered that an electron moving by itself in vacuum can possess an additional, potentially useful, property: orbital motion. Individual free electrons can also exist in combinations of these orbital states, and can even be made to exhibit orbital motions in opposite directions at the same time. The purpose of this project is to understand the fundamental nature of these new electron states by creating such mixed orbital states in electron beams, such as counter-rotating circular orbits, and to investigate new ways to measure the different types of orbital motion present in a mixture.  To do so, a commercial instrument that is typically used for nanoscale imaging (transmission electron microscope) will be used.  The electron beam inside this instrument will be made to pass through nanoscale gratings carefully designed with complicated patterns.  The effect on the beam will be measured using detectors downstream from the gratings.  If successful, this research will provide a new way to manipulate the electron as well as measure this new quantum property, paving the way for future technologies in quantum electronics and providing new ways to probe orbital motion in matter. 

Like all quantum mechanical waves, the wave function of a single free electron can be twisted on itself to form a quantum vortex. The purpose of this project is to investigate the fundamental quantum nature of these states by placing free electrons in coherent superpositions of orbital states using nanoscale diffraction holograms and other new electron optical devices. Electrons in superpositions of counter-rotating circular orbits form an electron interferometer in free space, and it can be used to probe geometric phases, spatial coherence, and orbital angular momentum-dependent phase shifts of the electron wavefunction. In addition to experiments preparing superpositions of orbital states, the project also develops ways to nondestructively measure and sort them, potentially providing new information from scattered electrons.

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of this project was to investigate orbital motion and complex spatial structures of free electrons. These properties can result from the wavelike nature electrons, but technologies for preparing and measuring such states have only recently been developed. The wavefunction describing each electron in a beam can be twisted in such a way that the electron possesses quantized angular momentum. The electron wavefunction can be shaped to impart electrons with mixtures of other momentum states, too – more generally called momentum superpositions. Under this project, researchers established technologies to coherently prepare free electrons with orbital angular momentum superpositions inside electron microscopes. These tools were then used to investigate how these states evolve and interact with other nanoscale systems. Finally, new methods were developed to measure orbital angular momentum properties of electrons.

Intellectual Merit

The technologies developed to prepare and measure electrons with arbitrary spatial modes enable new insights into quantum behavior and magnetic fields, and also provide a new tool for electron microscopy and spectroscopy. Technologies developed in this project are now being implemented at various electron microscopy instruments around the world. Project highlights include demonstrations of unusual electron beams that coil in free space, and electron interferometers that can measure electromagnetic fields, decoherence, and interactions with other objects. This work was documented and published in many peer-reviewed scientific journals, refereed conference papers, and PhD dissertations.

Broader Impacts

A major goal of the project was to engage first-year undergraduates in research starting in the summer of their first year of college. While the project involves the use of high technology to perform quantum mechanical experiments, this research is still accessible to the beginning physics student. Through this summer workshop series, dozens of students were introduced to electron microscopy, nanofabrication, imaging science, and introductory concepts of quantum mechanics, with a primary focus on developing skills in digital measurements and computational data analysis. The PI also engaged with the general public on this research by operating a “Science of Energy” booth and providing public lectures at the Oregon Country Fair, an arts and music festival attracting tens of thousands of visitors. Through this booth, attendees interact with various physics demos, ask questions of physicists, and are engaged on ways to express their own ideas in the form of a scientific question. Through these efforts, five graduating PhD students supported on this project gained experience communicating their research to diverse members of society.
